0553582038|5.0|What can I say that has not already been said? Hopefully quite a bit. To start with, this is one of the best fantasy series I have ever read, but if you're reading the reviews for A Feast for Crows you probably already have an opinion of your own (and if you got this far it's probably a favorable one). The action slows down in AFFC, so we don't get the fighting we're used to. This seems to be one of the most common complaints, so let me address it. The War of the Five Kings is pretty much over after the Red Wedding. Stannis is all but broken, Robb and Renly are both dead. The only major threat to the Iron Throne (that they know of) comes from the Iron Isles, and the Greyjoys don'[t have the strength to do much more than raid. Of course the battles will no longer come thick and fast, the south is at an uneasy peace. I felt that this book was portraying the consequences of such a devastating war and setting the stage for the endgame, really. It just added to the realism. Eventually everyone will run out of knights and smallfolk if they don't slow down the choppy.    The other most common issue is the lack of certain characters. I was disappointed not to find my boys Tyrion or Jon Snow taking center stage (or, indeed, any stage) as they rightfully should, but the cast has grown so large now that it would be virtually impossible to get everyone in. Some may say that's a bad thing, but I like seeing all these minor characters crop up. I want to know a little more about Tytos Blackwood and Ser Tallad, even if that means it takes a little longer to get to my favorites. Martin has a gift for writing rounded, believable people, and this demonstrates the awesome. We still have to put up with Cersei as a POV, but I didn't mind so much considering the direction the story took with her. All I'm saying.    The next book can't be that far away by now (I feel for the people who discovered these more than a couple of years back) and that should have more than enough Jon Snow, Tyrion, Dany, Bran, and cliffhanger resolution for us all, even those of us who still like Theon. All three of you.

B002HNA95E|1.0|I know some of you are getting a bit upset with that introduction but lets just get down to it. There is no way to really complain about what should have or what should have not been on this disc. It is impossible to put everyone's favorite on this two disc retrospective since everyone has their own opinion on which is the better madonna songs. After spanning nearly three decades it would be a very daunting task. Case in point while some people cried because \\"you'll see\\" wasn't included, thank god...I really hate that song....so there you go. I will only focus on what IS on it. How could anyone say a madonna retrospective is HORRIBLE you say? Well let me start by saying most die hard fans already have these version, so just so you're not confused as to what you got and what you really should have gotten. i'll break it down.     DISC ONE    1 hung up - album version.. (should have been the single version this one is way too long and gets a bit repetitious)    2 music - album version.     3 vogue - immaculate version.. (should have been the single version, which has only been available on a cd single, this version is more of a pop masterpiece)    4 4 minutes - album version    5 holiday - album version (should have been the single version that has never been released on cd with the exception of the 1,000 dollar import box set)    6 everybody - album version (there is a single/edit that's slightly different that's better)    7 like a virgin - album version (this one should have been the immaculate version which at least sounded better and stayed true to it's original form)    8 into the groove - 2 cut-maxi single version and the first time released on an official madonna release (bravo- at least it wasn't the immaculate version which was horrible and stripped away it's pure pop sound, this will be the song that defined the pop sound of the 80's)    9 like a prayer - album version (they should have put the 7 inch/edit version which has never been available on cd only ona rare promotional dj copy)    10 ray of light - album edit    11 sorry - single version (this version was segued on the confession's album so it's nice to have it singled out in it's entirety)    12 express yourself - this is an alternate version to the 7 inch single. (i hate to say it but the immaculate version is better)    13 open your heart - album version (there is an edit of the extended version that is the best version of this song..wish they would have included this)    14 borderline - immaculate version (they should have put the original single version that was released. The immaculate version strips the song of that great madonna sound that made her work sound like a true artist when every critic described her as just a \\"bubble-gum\\" star. This version proved them all wrong. It has not been available on cd and can only be found on the 1,000 dollar singles box set)    15 secret - album edit (what can i say if it got any longer I don't think i could stand it: on a side not the single club remix is better)    16 erotica - album edit (taken from the erotica album that was overlooked at the time due to her sex book. The one they should have included should have been the original 7 inch edit version when it was first released. It has never been availble on cd. But in my opinion the extended video version is the best one)    6 burning up - album version (there's a single extended edit that the only reason it's a toss up is because at the very end the background singing is slightly more noticeable and makes the song better because of it)    7 crazy for you - vision quest version (immaculate version sounds better while also staying true to it's original form)    8 who's that girl - soundtrack version (there is a very rare edit of the extended remix that is the best verson of this song, but this version is what everyone rememebers and it is a good one)    9 frozen - album edit (there is a single edit that's only 4 min's and 47 seconds long and is way better. The longer versions gets to be repititous)    10 miles away - album version (the morgan page edit is the best version)    11 take a bow - album version (this song is like her acting a bit over dramatic and just a bit too much. It gets right to the point instead of being all over drawn with the before and middle piano break. There is an even shorter version that's rare but it has the beginning piano and even the middle piano break removed entirely and if you can find it it's the best version)    13 beautiful stranger - album version (this is where madonna went wrong in my opinion. What can I say..hate it and a waste of madonna creativity.     14 hollywood - album vesion (another reason why this album tanked. The white-duck single mix is the best version of this mess if you had to listen to it.     15 die another day - album version (I still don't know what this song is about? Kinda feels like it could have been released during her like a virgin era.     As you can see now, most of these selections were pulled straight from the immaculate album, the greatest hits vol 2, and from the album's themselves. All of which every die hard madonna fan already has. They should have put the single versions that were originally released because that is what we remember hearing that made Madonna who she is. A POP ICON. Especially since they have not been available up to this point. They failed to do that. And for those who say that it's good to include these versions so future madonna fans will discover her work. They will discover versions that did not make that first initial impact that made you notice the sound, the style, and importantly the music that is madonna.     On another side note: This 2-disc retrospective was madonna's last contract obligation she has with warner brothers so maybe the track listing as well as the selected versions were purposely chosen to save these rarities for a future madonna box set who knows.
B00005T30L|4.0|In some ways, the film \\"Ghost World(2001)\\" is brilliant. Few films have captured on such a realistic and intimate level, the plight of so many people both lost and alone. It's a portrait of modern society that really  should be discussed alot more than it is.<br /><br />The plot follows two High School pals(Thora Birch and Scarlet Johansson) and there travels  into adult life and responsibility. The film begins very humorously with the sardonic duo's comments on the plastic people that occupy everyday society, both biting and honest. However, there maturity,and ultimately, purpose is challenged, when one of there pranks goes awry on a lonely record collector played by Steve Buscemi. After this encounter, the duo become more seperate. Johansson begins to mellow out and finds a job and responsibility, while Birch attempts to find her place in the world as everything chnages around her.<br /><br />The acting in \\"Ghost World\\" is among the best presented this decade. Birch and Johansson are both excellent and it was not surprising to see them gain careers from this picture. They are both funny and exceptionally beautiful young women which sets a basis for one of the film's thesis', particularly in Birch's case. Birch is an exceptionally pretty and very well formed young woman who can't seem to find friends or a date. Men barely notice her and it's based more around her choice of clothing and intellectual side than anything. Birch's subtle signs of loneliness are very real and reflect many young people that i've known. Her seemingly sardonic asides and attitude merely masking her yearning for acceptance and love that she only encounters seldomly. The eventual relationship she has with Buscemi's character is very heartfelt and moving throughout and forms one of the anchors to the picture.<br /><br />Johansson's character is representive of that character that many of us have to become in order to survive in society. While intelligent and looking down ona grea number of society, she ultimately is forced to conform to survive and her needs and interests change as a result. She becomes largely absent from the second half of the picture but her friendship with Birch is important and moving nonetheless. The subtle farewell scene they have at the conclusion is so quietly painful.<br /><br />Buscemi deserved an Oscar for this, his best role. An almost clueless loner who collects records and old paraphenalia, admitting that they act as a replacement for the lack of people within his life. He is a realistic and sympathetic character and always interesting throughout. The actor has made a career out of playing eccentrics and weirdos and while some may classify his character as a \\"weirdo\\", he's really one of the most normal and human characters i've seen depicted in cinema in quite some time.<br /><br />This is an exceptionally well directed film and thankfully never falls to the excessive fast-paced editing and new age nonsense that distracts from so many modern productions. It's well paced and always is the film entertaining and enthralling.<br />It's unfortunate that the ending is so ambiguous. While, it is understandable what the author's intentions may have been, that of having Birch either drift away from life and dissapear and/or be swallowed up in the shallow recesses of mature monotony, this does not make a fully suitable ending. After two hours with these characters, the final seven minutes of the film are somewhat dissapointing, even if they can be forgiveable.<br /><br />Despite this ending though, \\"Ghost World\\" still ranks as one of the most intelligent and best acted films of this decade and is highly reccomended for fans of Dark Comedy and Existentionalist Cinema.forced to conform to survive and her needs and interests change as a result. She becomes largely absent from the second half of the picture but her friendship with Birch is important and moving nonetheless. The subtle farewell scene they have at the conclusion is so quietly painful.    Buscemi deserved an Oscar for this, his best role. An almost clueless loner who collects records and old paraphenalia, admitting that they act as a replacement for the lack of people within his life. He is a realistic and sympathetic character and always interesting throughout. The actor has made a career out of playing eccentrics and weirdos and while some may classify his character as a \\"weirdo\\", he's really one of the most normal and human characters i've seen depicted in cinema in quite some time.    This is an exceptionally well directed film and thankfully never falls to the excessive fast-paced editing and new age nonsense that distracts from so many modern productions. It's well paced and always is the film entertaining and enthralling.  It's unfortunate that the ending is so ambiguous. While, it is understandable what the author's intentions may have been, that of having Birch either drift away from life and dissapear and/or be swallowed up in the shallow recesses of mature monotony, this does not make a fully suitable ending. After two hours with these characters, the final seven minutes of the film are somewhat dissapointing, even if they can be forgiveable.    Despite this ending though, \\"Ghost World\\" still ranks as one of the most intelligent and best acted films of this decade and is highly reccomended for fans of Dark Comedy and Existentionalist Cinema.
B002FRNCG0|3.0|The rock band Paramore hasn't been without its share of problems in its history, and some of that anger gets vented out on their latest release.  Although the album cover depicts the darker, more serious tone of Paramore's third full-length record, secondarily it could represent the bands' spreading its wings stylistically...growing away from the formulaic, commercialized sound that dominated their previous effort, the Platinum \\"Riot!\\".    While \\"Brand New Eyes\\" starts off with two catchy, up-tempo numbers tailor-made to get fans off their feet singing along at concerts, the rest of the compilation includes enough variety in tempo, instrumentation and style that critics will find it much more difficult to claim all the songs sound the same this time around.    Musicianship is excellent.  Hayley Williams sings her heart out.  The production is superb (Rob Cavallo, who's worked with artists David Cook, Goo Goo Dolls and Green Day to name a few, gives us punchy drums, grungy, powerful guitars and clean vocals).    But for some reason, it isn't happening for me.  I've been listening over and over wanting to like it.  I like parts of several songs...the finger-picked clean guitar part at the beginning and other points in \\"Playing God\\", the pre-chorus and a small part in the chorus of \\"Brick By Boring Brick\\", the chorus of \\"Turn It Off\\", the verse of \\"Feeling Sorry\\".  \\"Looking Up\\" and \\"All I Wanted\\" are better, but still nothing to write home about.  \\"Misguided Ghosts\\" seems like it should be a beautiful song, but it's not moving me.  And I don't like \\"The Only Exception\\" at all...it doesn't sound even remotely like a Paramore song.  Nothing here makes me want to dig deeper into the supposedly better lyrics.    The only thing I can think of?  I miss those formulaic, commercial Paramore songs...the \\"Misery Business\\" and \\"That's What You Get\\"-type songs.  I miss the soaring melodies that have been sending chills down my spine...I'm not hearing them here.     I think most fans will like \\"Brand New Eyes\\".  But I'm just not hearing any blow-your-socks-off songs here.  I may be wrong (and I hope I am), but I don't see this album having a very long life after initial sales.  I recommend giving these songs a good listen before you buy, because you may find you're not feeling it either.

074357818X|4.0|Produced by Simon AND SHOESTER AUDIO USA<br />When I was preparing to listen to this short story audio book, my instinct was that this book was about baseball, my second instinct was that the book was about a famous international baseball player named Tom Gordon.<br />My third instinct was that this would be a light-hearted story about Trisha McFarlands infatuation with her favourite sporting hero.<br /><br />However THE GIRL WHO LOVED TOM GORDON.<br />Is about being lost and alone in a dark wood, somewhere that no one can see you no one can hear you, no one will ever find you and no one knows you are there.<br />  Saturday 12:00pm, the McFarland family were going on a weekend treek through the woods.<br />Nine year -old Trisha was hounding her older brother Pete about the talented and good looking Tom Gordon.<br />Before Pete can answer Trisha decides she needs a toilet stop, when she returns her mother and brother are nowhere to be seen.<br /><br />One of the most frightening aspects of this book is when she begins to hear voices inside her head.<br />My favourite moment is when Trisha, starving and naked comes across a thorn bush with wild berries. 0393327655|4.0|I came into this book already believing in Harris' central thesis. In the first few chapters he brilliantly sets forth arguments that would be difficult to adequately refute. However, I have some serious qualms with his final two chapters. Early on in the book Harris argues the evils of religion by demonstrating just how barbaric religion can cause people to behave by giving examples of early christian torture devices that personally made me quite uneasy. Harris explains how these sessions of torture would always result in false confessions. Harris even gives an example of a judge who began to feel suspicious of the reliability of torture to elicit meaningful confessions. Upon the judge voicing his concern that torture may elicit false confessions about being a witch, he himself was tortured and then confessed to being a witch. Yet, Harris then proceeds, in the second to last chapter, to defend torture if it will help elicit any response. He claims that anything is better than nothing. It seemed to me that Harris contradicted himself and reserved the right to torture to the \\"enlightened\\" modern thinkers, while condemning the medieval torturers. I feel that Harris' attitude toward torture is that medieval torture was wrong because it was done in the name of religion, but modern forms of torture are acceptable because they may save a persons life. However, to me, torture is torture regardless of the intentions or reasons for torturing.<br />The final chapter I found to be peculiar. Harris seems to embrace, although he claims otherwise, the teachings of Buddhism. Either way, I found the final chapter irrelevant to the book as a whole. The premise of the book was to debunk the validity faith, not advocate a replacement.<br />I gave the book 4 stars instead of 5 because of the last two chapters. I know I focused on the negatives in this review, but the book is very enjoyable and I would highly recommend it.
B0029LHW4U|5.0|When Alice in Chains released their self-titled album in 1995, it showed the band moving in a different direction from the one they'd explored previously. Jerry Cantrell was singing lead on more tracks than ever before, Layne Staley's vocals were heavily layered (double-tracked), and the grunge sound they'd had turned into a more sludge-metal type sound. Staley died 7 years after the release of that album and it appeared for a while that Alice in Chains had died with him. I worship Layne Staley, but I realize he was not solely responsible for creating the Alice in Chains sound; but, he did leave a large void when he passed away. Since Alice in Chains announced they were recording a new album with new vocalist/guitarist William DuVall, the question running through people's minds has been \\"Can they do it without Layne?\\" Well, after steadily listening to this album since it leaked, I can tell you, in all honesty, that they can.    \\"Black Gives Way to Blue\\" picks up pretty much where that last album left off. This is not \\"Dirt Pt. II,\\" but Alice in Chains for 2009 and even with Staley gone, the album still retains the recognizable Alice in Chains sound. There are moments where you can not only feel Staley's presence, you can almost hear his voice. While William DuVall is technically Layne Staley's replacement, Jerry Cantrell handles a large majority of lead vocal duties...But make no mistake, this is not a Jerry Cantrell solo album. This is very much an Alice in Chains album. When DuVall and Cantrell harmonize together in the way Staley and Cantrell did so many years ago, it's pretty clear that Alice in Chains is back.    Here is a track-by-track review;    1. All Secrets Known-Begins with a terrific guitar riff and instead of launching into a brutal, blistering metal song becomes simply a subtle track about moving on. \\"There's no going back to the place we started from,\\" sort of perfectly sums up their desire to record this album despite the cries of \\"It won't be the same\\" from many fans. (4/5)    2. Check My Brain-Another great riff; also the 2nd single from the album. DuVall lurks in the background, only really handling harmony duties with Cantrell, but this song rocks and is just as good as old Alice in Chains. (5/5)    3. Last of My Kind-On the third track, DuVall handles the lead vocals and his voice, by itself, works very well in AIC. DuVall also penned this track...This is a catchy, hard-rocking song; one of my favorites on the album. (5/5)    4. Your Decision-Instantly reminiscent of \\"Nutshell.\\" It's a great/beautiful track with a fantastic guitar solo by Cantrell (who also handles a good  majority of the lead vocals). (5/5)    5. A Looking in View-The first single Alice in Chains released from this album. A little over 7 minutes, this track instantly got me excited for the new album. This doesn't just sound like classic Alice in Chains, it IS classic Alice in Chains. Great vocal harmonies, great music, and a terrific chorus. There's parts of this song that literally sound like Layne Staley has been brought back to life (5/5)    6. When the Sun Rose Again-A beautiful song that I intitally wasn't too fond of. Sounds like an extension of the \\"Jar of Flies\\" sound. (5/5)    7. Acid Bubble-Almost 7 minutes long; One of the best on the album, but also took a bit to grow on me...The song is character by slow verses sung simultaneously by Cantrell and DuVall, with DuVall singing the chilling bridge of the song before launching into a brilliantly harmonized chorus, and finally there's the heavy interlude. This song is a masterpiece. (5/5)    8. Lesson Learned-Has been one of my favorite tracks on the album since I first heard it. It's a great song and when Cantrell & DuVall sing \\"In your darkest hour, you strike gold,\\" I get goosebumps. It's really a fantastic song. (5/5)    9. Take Her Out-This is the weakest song on the album, in my opinion. It's not a bad song by any means, it's just weaker than the other tracks...However, it does have a good chorus. (4/5)    10. Private Hell-I really didn't like this song at first, but now I find it one of the most powerful. The vocals here are very Layne Staley-esque and it's a very powerful, personal song. This, more than almost all the others, reminded me of classic AIC. In the vein of \\"Down in a Hole,\\" give this song some time if you don't like it immediately. It's a great track (5/5)    11. Black Gives Way to Blue-The final track has some haunting guitar courtesy of Cantrell and piano by Elton John; dedicated to the memory of Staley, it's a beautiful, haunting, and touching song. A great track and a great way to close the album.    Jerry Cantrell has been outspoken about his goal not to destroy the Alice in Chains legacy with this album and I'm beyond proud to report that he did no such thing. This is a more-than-worthy entry in a great band's career, but more importantly...It's a great album, by itself. This is not a retread of Alice in Chains or an attempt to capture the same magic as before...This is just a fantastic album by a hard-working, musically gifted band that would be a great album no matter what moniker the band carried with them. Listen with an open-mind and be happy that AIC is moving on from the memory of Layne Staley to still give us fans great music. I guarantee that Layne Staley is smiling right now and would be pleased with the great work these four guys have done.    GRADE: A

That sound very good for a new movie, considering the variety of backgrounds and preferences of the Amazon reviewers. And what a movie it is! 0385504225|4.0|Dan Brown, in [[ASIN:0385504225 The Lost Symbol]] takes us on another thrilling ride through the \\"Ancient Mysteries.\\" Robert Langdon, the Harvard Symbologist, carries us along through numerous brink-of-death situations, giving the book edge-of-your-seat momentum.   Numerous reviews have discussed the plot, so I will move directly to my comments.    First, I enjoyed the amusement park ride.  Since I am often reading non-fiction titles, when I pick up fiction I want to be entertained, drawn into the story, intrigued. I read it in one sitting. The puzzles (ok, I confess I am a Sudoku fan, the magic square) the misdirection, the chases, I enjoyed the ride.      I also enjoyed these quotes sprinkled throughout the book. My favorites:     \\"Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.\\" Arthur C. Clarke, Futurist,  (The Lost Symbol, pg 86) Instantly brought to mind my first experiences with a fax machine! The paper gets there how???     \\"Wide acceptance of an idea does not prove its validity.\\" The Lost Symbol, pg 79  I love this one.  It seems everyday our news reports include  lady-in-the-Laundromat  or   the man-in-the-deli  opinions validating a popular (but uninformed, unsubstantiated) opinion. Of course, here Brown uses it to fuel his challenge-all-religion stance... belittling myths of his choosing.   Setting that aside, I still love the quote.    \\"If thoughts affect the world, then we must be very careful how we think. Destructive thoughts have influence, too, and we all know it's far easier to destroy than to create.\\"  Lost Symbol, pg 501.  Can we make this every school's motto?  I'm a positive thinker, I'm a half-full glass person, and have witnessed the power of prayer, so this resonates with me.  In fact, when Brown's story descends to the depths, I cringed and almost stopped reading.     Thirdly, I thoroughly enjoyed the setting of Washington DC.  On a recent visit to Alexandria, VA driving to the Old Town on Carlisle Drive, we stumbledupon stunning monument/museum called the George Washington Masonic National Memorial.  I had completely forgotten that Washington was a freemason, and was amazed how \\"unhidden\\" it was, for this society with secrets.  Brown mentions it in the book, along with numerous buildings and their histories.  As an avid reader, and a book professional, I thoroughly enjoyed the character's \\"ride\\" on the circulation belt... something I would have loved to do!   The Washington setting will undoubtedly boost the attraction of these majestic buildings.     On the negative side, I was distracted by the believability of his facts.  As a widely read person, I was often thinking that doesn't sound true, I should research that.  When I pick up fiction, I don't expect to get homework assignments!  If you can remind yourself to stick to the story, and not remember the inaccuracies as fact, the read could still work.  When you recommend a book to a friend, the fear is they could trustingly embrace it as historically accurate, hence the caution.      For example, the Akedah is a historically substantiated story of Abraham, in obedience to God's command, willing to sacrifice his own son, Isaac. God intervenes with a substitute sacrifice, showing His love for Abraham.   In the Lost Symbol, pg 445, Brown invents an actual knife; the \\"Akedah Knife\\", gives it mystical properties and a \\"destiny\\" to fulfill.  All the while alluding that his story, Peter Solomon/Zachary and Abraham/Isaac is one and the same.    Brown's creating the son's desire to self-sacrifice and involve his father, twists this historical story into a meaningless one.   One wonders why Brown's fiction needs to dig at the tenets of the various religious worldviews.  Is it to create the controversy that sells lots of books?  You decide.    Throughout the story we observe the premise \\"how to die\\", over and over.  I, on the other hand would have celebrated the characters that portray, how to live. The love of a friend, sister, brother, fellow believer, to go to whatever lengths necessary to help.        Despite the inaccuracies, I would recommend this title to fiction readers who love to discuss the latest bestseller `round cocktails or the water cooler, readers who can separate fact from fiction, and to readers, who can suspend their disbelief and just enjoy the ride.
B001TODCII|4.0|I thought this was a good movie.  Liam Neeson plays a father whose daughter is taken by human traffickers.  He's a retired government agent and knows how to kick butt.  He does a lot of killing and head busting in this movie and they all deserve it.  This movie makes you wish you could fight like Liam and take on several bad guys at one time.  It did have the Steven Segal and the Jason Statham fight feel; lots of bad guys against one.  It is a good action film worth seeing more than once and even though Liam does look older, he pulled the vengeful father part off quite nice.

I always wish artists well and in Witney's case I am beside myself with relief and joy that her album made it so fast to #1 on Billboard (of course I checked!).  There are few things more emotionally satisfying than a well-earned comeback, and girl, ya did it!  Mad love.

B002JYPV3G|5.0|I've been a Slipknot fan since '99 when I saw them on Ozzfest, and like another reviewer said, this is the fourth time I've purchased this album. There's really nothing here that can't be found elsewhere, other than the Wait and Bleed demo. Purity is back, but the Frail Limb Nursery intro is missing... that's not a big deal to me since I have the original pressing with Frail Limb Nursery/Purity, but I can see how its absence could disappoint fans who weren't fortunate enough to pick that version up before it was discontinued. Sure it's just a 45 second intro, but it's just as much a part of the original release as any other track and it made for a smoother transition between Tattered & Torn and Purity. If the disk's running time was an issue I'm sure they could have easily dedicated one disk to the original release and put the bonus tracks on another. The band had a hand in deciding what tracks went on this special edition and they wanted it to be perfect, there has to be a better excuse than that...    Honestly, the DVD is the real reason to pick this up. It has three vidoes (which were already available on [[ASIN:B00007BHOE Slipknot - Disasterpieces]], definitely a must have for any Slipknot fan), an entire live set recorded at Dynamo Open Air Festival in 2000 that was originally intended for a second home movie, and a ton of randomness from various live shows and offstage footage strung together in a similar (but much more cohesive and enjoyable) fashion to their third DVD release, [[ASIN:B000BNJOUI Voliminal: Inside the Nine]]. It would have been nice to have had retrospective interviews with a few members of the band discussing how they feel about the album after 10 years and the success it brought them, but considering how busy the band's mouthpieces (Corey, Joey, and Clown) are even when they're not touring, that might have been nearly impossible to arrange.
B0029LHW4U|5.0|The reviews are in, and I'm not in the least bit surprised how positive they've been. Like many, I was skeptical about this reunion at first, but it completely delivers. The new AIC manages to pay tribute to the monumentally influential sound they forged in their first albums, mixing the classic psychedelic sludgy stuff with the introspective and unique acoustic melodies. As many reviewers have mentioned, they introduce Duvall in an understated fashion and bring him along nicely. While Staley's raw power and emotion will never be forgotten, Duvall harmonizes beautifully with Cantrell and adds a nice vocal range as well as guitar playing and songwriting chops. I didn't like him at first when they reformed, but after listening to Black Gives Way to Blue, I believe he's a perfect fit.    Definitely worthy of 5 stars.  I love Pearl Jam too, and I was severely disappointed in their latest effort, so I calls 'em as I sees 'em. So excited that AIC has picked up right where they left off, and I can't wait to see how they continue to evolve on future albums.

B002KVSJ64|5.0|In writing a review of \\"Dear Agony\\" I must first say I realize that I am writing a review of a Breaking Benjamin album and not expecting them to be Muse, Tool, Thrice, a Jack White project, or anyone else who is trying to experimentally push musical boundaries. I admire those artists, and greatly respect their talents, but come on, that's not what BB has ever been about. I think this album is every bit as good, and better in some respects, than anything they have ever done.    With that being said, I think this is a very solid, cohesive album. The production is outstanding, everything sounds clear and precise. Ben's vocals range from brooding and smooth to deeply aggressive and growling.  The lyrics cover familiar territory ranging from suffering and anger to determination, hope, and restoration. Definitely some familiar dark territory is covered, but there is one small twist here from old subject matter. Pervading throughout the album seems to be a theme of sickness and recovery. It's very direct in the songs \\"Dear Agony\\" and \\"Fade Away\\", but there seems to be a reference in almost every song.  I can't deny I have become increasingly curious about Ben's health since he missed some previous concert dates.  Regardless, I think Ben's talented voice and genuine emotional delivery are what keep this band from being another face in the crowd.    The band seems to try a couple of different techniques on this album, but nothing that would constitute a drastic change in sound. The guitars melodically weave around the vocals at some points, and then grind and drive with solid, heavy riffs in others. The heavy distortion of Aaron's guitar endures from track to track with few short guitar solos spread throughout the album.  Mark's thundering bass lines rotate between blending into the grinding riffs, to breaking out into the forefront in some songs.  I really enjoy Chad Szeliga's drumming, he finds ways to insert cymbal crashes and riffs into songs that I find unique (see crash cymbal in chorus of \\"What lies beneath\\".)  It is very solid musicianship, which employs much of what has become their signature sound.  This creates something that fans will surely like, but critics will for sure attack for lack of originality.    The album has a consistent flow to it; I don't see any track as filler. I would say that it is better than \\"Phobia\\" in that respect.  Although, I doubt they will score a hit as big as \\"Breath\\" with this album. \\"I Will Not Bow\\" has already charted better than \\"Until the End\\" and I'm sure there will be more singles to follow. Only four tracks exceed the four minute mark.  \\"Fade Away\\", \\"Give me a Sign\\", \\"Crawl\\", \\"Dear Agony\\", and \\"Anthem of the Angels\\" could all be single material. \\"Hopeless\\" is also an early favorite of mine, but is a little heavier than most of their radio releases.     The songs on this album are at least on par with, if not better than, their previous platinum efforts. It's also produced better than anything they've ever put out.  Once again I'm sure fans will appreciate it and consider it a welcome addition to the band's catalog.  Critics of the band or of the genre will not be converted by this album. Depending on your stance, the band's strong or weak point is that they sound like themselves. Maybe I'm just a fan, but I was waiting for this one to come out for a while and I am not disappointed at all.  If you have enjoyed BB in the past, I would highly encourage you to pick this up.  I look forward to seeing some of the new material performed live!
B001TKKAJG|5.0|Having bought music on vinyl and paid again for the same music on CD, I am now going through a third phase of buying whatever is available in the genres I like on SACD.  SACD has the convenience of CD with much superior sound quality - I actually prefer it to LPs.    This SACD of a classic is highly recommended.  All else is gaslight?

Everybody will like these cupcakes, vegan or not. There are so many creative and easy recipes, there's something for everybody. B0029LHW4U|3.0|Since my review is fairly long here is the condensed version for those with a short attention span: If you liked Alice in Chains for their chunky riffs, acoustic textures, harmonies and quality song-writing then you will thoroughly enjoy Black Gives Way to Blue. If you loved Alice in Chains more because of the raw emotion driven by the powerful, soulful and artistic vocal approach and sonic mood swings, you will be largely disappointed. If you liked them for both qualities, you'll have mixed feelings. Personally, the reason I fell in love with Alice in Chains was for the emotion and feel largely due to Layne Staley, and seeing how the only singer they have with any soulfulness now (Duvall) is largely underused on BGWTB, it ends up coming short of the mark for an Alice in Chains record, but makes the grade as a Jerry Cantrell record and then some. Of all of the Jerry Cantrell or Alice in Chains records, it sounds closest to Degradation Trip. Now for the full review...     Right when we all thought the Alice in Chains and Stone Temple Pilots reunions were the story of the year, along came Creed to spoil the party, trying to capitalize on milking the market. Creed's return is a little late though, because to many of us Alice in Chains never really disappeared anyways, at least in their current form. If you're not sure what I'm talking about, I have to ask you where the heck were you when Boggy Depot was released in 1998, or when the masterpiece Degradation Trip was released in 2002? If you call yourself an Alice in Chains fan you own at least one of those and used them to fill the void. More or less they are just as Alice-y as this release, just without the name attached.     Nonetheless, they returned after those semi-Alice releases with friends to raise money for the victims of the tsunami in 2005, only to follow that up with a self-organized world tour with Duvall taking on the role of lead singer since the VH1 Heart special. One thing led to another, and naturallythe result is a record of long-awaited new material that was largely unexpected to ever come about after Layne Staley's passing. Alice in Chains' legacy with the troubled, irreplaceable front man who suffered internally into unfortunate oblivion was starting to turn into a story of legend. Now it's sadly turned into a point of contention between fans of old versus new AIC.    Though lacking the band name to credit, the previously mentioned Boggy Depot and Degradation Trip sound as much as Alice in Chains as the new release in several ways. In fact the latter is every bit as impressive as Black Gives Way to Blue if not more so at times. Even without as much presence by Kinney or Inez, it still sounds even more like 'the next Alice record'. The difference between Degradation Trip and BGWTB? The band name, i.e. a stamp of approval of sorts. It's unfortunate that in order to hit a wider audience they had no choice but to stamp the AIC brand on the music. Jerry Cantrell as a solo artist, though every bit as good as Alice without Staley, is just a hard sell -- so much so that the Roadrunner made him release a condensed, single-disc version of Degradation Trip to test the waters before they would agree to print the entire two-disc compilation.  The band members can iterate and rehash every possible way their reason(s) for keeping the Alice name alive they can think of - celebration of a legacy or adding to the amazing history being the main ones they mention. But the main result of this choice, desired or not, is that it ensures that they hit a broader audience and garner more attention, and as a result get the recognition they actually deserve for their hard work.    The band members all know how iconic Staley was to the band and the risk involved with alienating fans. They all knew what a risky decision it was to continue on as Alice, including William Duvall, who admirably marches on the stage and stares down legions of dedicated fans as he growls out words he knows hecan't relate to directly in any regard on songs such as Sickman, God Am and Sludge Factory. He can't change the fact that he's not really fit to sing most of these lyrics (and I stress that no one really is), and he deserves an applause for having the guts to get up and try his best to convince us otherwise, and succeeding in many ways by digging down deep to find his own ways to relate to the lyrics and feel of the songs. I had a hunch he would be more digestible on the new record, singing fewer lyrics and melodies not formed by Staley. Surely enough, this is the case. In fact, I wish his voice was even more prominent. If I had one large complaint about this new record, the lack of presence from Duvall would be it.    So here we arrive, fittingly at the date of September 29 for the release of Black Gives Way to Blue. The fact that they are releasing it on this date speaks volumes about the band's confidence in the new material. In 1992 this date marked the start of a long journey when Alice was catapulted into mainstream success with Dirt -- a journey that took a harsh turn after essentially two straight years of nonstop touring. 17 years later, in 2009 this date marks a rebirth, and this time around they are more mature, weathered, and as a band they've changed a bit with a different bassist and obviously a huge void left by Staley. As Cantrell sings in the opening track, this is a new beginning. 17 years down the line and a lot has changed for the band and the music industry. At first you might think how it's amazing, that through all of these massive changes they can still churn out music that is still relative. That is, until you realize that all of their records are timeless, and are thus also still relative. That to me is far more impressive and makes the accomplishment of a new record sort of an afterthought. This is because Alice has always been more about making music that is focused more of being an art form than a way of 'rocking out'. This record tips the scales a little too far to the rocking out spectrum for my tastes, but more on that later.    Alice has always had a knack for having the first song on the record set the tone musically and lyrically. On Facelift they start right in with the death-aware reality check, on Dirt they lead off with hard-hitting internal despair and hopelessness, and on self-titled they had Grind, which I consider to be the song version of a meat-axe, with the riffs pounding and tearing away at flesh and bone that set the tone for an album to be a form of biting back and questioning the intentions of anyone including but not limited to God him/her/itself. All of these songs set the overall tone of their respective record pretty accurately, both sonically and lyrically. The case is no different on BGWTB. As such the first subject matter they address are all the \\"secrets\\" we know -- that they can't go back to where they were before as they are changed forever and haunted by the loss of Staley, but it's time to move on. Slowly and methodically, All Secrets Known opens the new chapter in a way that will probably shock you if you've never heard Jerry's solo albums. Still this song is sort of on the tame side for an Alice opener, which feels to me like 'yes we are back, but don't expect it to be quite the same.\\" This turns out to be pretty accurate summation of the album as a whole.    Coming off as 'now that we have that out of the way, let's get to rocking out', track two takes us right into the first single, Check My Brain. The main riff has a few strums with a bend that recall Angry Chair except with the bend on the first chord instead of the last. The melody, repetition and harmonizing show more similarities to that song, too. In short, this song sounds how it would've turned out if Jerry Cantrell wrote Angry Chair's lyrics and music instead of Staley. It turns out that it's not terrible, actually, just a bit less atmospheric and lot more radio friendly. Overall, the record is more aimed at being a loud and in-your-face rock record as opposed to focusing on overall atmosphere as on Facelift, Sap, Dirt, Jar of Flies and Tripod, which I will later explain how this hurts it when it comes to longevity. For the record I am writing this as I listen, of course.    Finally we get to the long awaited first and only song where Duvall takes lead pretty much on his own on the vocals. This is what I had personally been dying to hear and am disappointed not to hear more of. Many have said, and I can't help but agree, that this tune sounds like it was pulled right out of the Dirt sessions with the guitar grooves that sound like Dam That River was crammed together with Rain When I Die and pushed out of a cheese grater. Duvall's vocals are notably more enjoyable than Cantrell's, as he knows how to sing with more conviction. Favorite song at this point in the record.    Your Decision comes on as the first acoustic-based track and follows a very similar chord progression as Angel Eyes from Degradation Trip, but just feels like it drags itself to the finish with the help of an electric solo that anchors it. It's decent but it's not very memorable. Probably the worst song at this point in the record, and perhaps the worst one on the entire album. It's too simple and too basic. While I usually appreciate Alice's stripped down songs, this one could have benefitted from stronger, more convincing lead vocals. Imagine a song like Nutshell being sang by Cantrell. It wouldn't be excellent. When a song is stripped down it needs stronger vocals to contrast the lighter music.    Next up is A Looking in View, which was actually the first song released from the new record via the band's website, and I can't help but hear this and think 'this is almost how Died would have sounded if it was actually finished.' It's in the same direction, vibe and pace, but with more polish and completion. It's a little bit too long for the lack of complexity it offers, but it's one of the better songs despite this.     At this point in the record, I have realized that this new material misses Staley's lyrical complexity just as much as it misses his actual vocals. No more of those long-drawn interruptions we got on tunes like Sludge Factory or Frogs, or even smack in the middle of songs like Sickman and A Little Bitter. But more noticeably lacking is how the overall verse lyrics miss quality and diversity in terms of both melody and content. Those are minor complaints though, as with either more atmosphere or a larger role from Duvall, this album could have been even better than Dirt.    Back to the songs. When the Sun Rose Again is another acoustic number that has the ambiance of Sap more than Jar of Flies with Kinney on the bongos. This mood caters to Cantrell's vocal style very well. As perhaps the best acoustic song on here it just so happens to lead right into the best electric song -- Acid Bubble. With an opening lick that echoes shades of Bleed the Freak, the pace plods along much like Frogs. This song is both the fastest and slowest song on the record. Fastest in a literal sense and also because good songs always seem to end when you were still wanting more. My favorite AIC vibes are all touched upon here -- the meticulous chord progressions of self-titled, the off-kilter tempo changes of Dirt and the best harmonizing on the entire record.    Unfortunately it's hard to follow up an amazing song like that, but Lesson Learned actually does a decent job. It has that catchy sound that you would expect to find on Cantrell's solo records. It's a great song, it's just not what you would expect from an AIC album. It doesn't really deserve a knock for that. Finally we're getting towards the end and Cantrell is the one who's complaining that 'time is dragging on' on Take Her Out. By the end of this song I must admit that I share his sentiments. Like the first acoustic track, this song could really do well with better lead vocals. Where the heck has Duvall gone? He's supposed to be the new front man and he's been basically absent on the last two songs that really could've used him. I bet these two songs (Take Her Out and Lesson Learned) are better live, seeing how Duvall's usually more take-charge in that setting.    Private Hell finally brings a sigh of relief as I thought this record was about to spiral downhill after a solid start. Duvall is back into the mix again as he sings backup on the verses and lead on the choruses. It delivers a sledgehammer to the skull with its layering, and really shows the band's potential.    The final song is an acoustic goodbye to Layne Staley. With Elton John lending a hand or two on the piano, it's one of the most beautifully depressing songs in the AIC catalogue. While we've known Layne's been gone for such a long time, this song really makes the unfortunate reality set in, and in a hard way. It really has that cementing effect to it -- just imagine being in an elevator going up that suddenly breaks and starts to fall fifty floors. It reminds me of why I loved Alice in the first place: their music deals with reality, and reminds you that often times reality sucks, and somehow it's comforting to know that it doesn't just suck for yourself.    While people still dispute (and probably will until the world ends) about replacing Staley and/or continuing on as Alice, they're overlooking the only truly important question they should focus on: does the new record stand up to other Alice records? This should be the question asked regardless of whether Staley was in the band or not. When you look at both sides of the equation that made them so great in the first place -- the powerful singing and song writing duo with now half of this gone, the answer is no. It does stand up well to the other Jerry Cantrell records, however. In fact I would say Degradation Trip gets closer to meeting AIC standards than BGWTB, though it still falls a bit short.    That said, there is something undeniably absent on this record much like its cousin, Degradation Trip. As I mentioned earlier it's missing an overall atmosphere due to too much emphasis on being purely loudness of rock. Stripping down the music to a certain point and contrasting it with powerful vocals helps give a record an overall vibe and pulse. This is something they could've accomplished better if Duvall was used more. It's too bad they didn't use his vocal prowess to their full advantage.    When I close my eyes and listen to Dirt it takes me into a nightmarish doomsday, or self-titled takes me into a roller coaster of whimsical mood swings. Each AIC release prior to this had a definable artistic sonic identity, where if you had to, you could listen to one song from each record and easily figure out which one it came from based on its feel. This record suffers from an identity crisis in comparison, these identities are what gave previous Alice works their long-lasting appeal, and also the artistic appeal. Some days I'm feeling into the Staley-induced mood swings and attitude of self-titled, other days the hopelessness of Dirt and Sap, or infrequently the funkier attitude of Facelift, and for some occasions the semi-uplifting ambiance of Jar of Flies.     Think of it in the same ways as looking at paintings -- they all have a mood and pure emotion attached to them. I don't ever see myself 'feeling like Black Gives Way to Blue' for these emotionally therapeutic motivations. This record lacks that type of identity or heart that makes an album have a life of its own inside your head, as does Degradation Trip. Ironically a heart is the image on the cover (maybe saying they wear their heart on their sleeve, seems rather cliche to me). It turns out that a heart is what seems to be mostly absent on the inside of the case. While it still gets my recommendation, it will be a long time, or possibly never before I am willing to say that Black Gives Way to Blue has the long lasting effect of any of the other Alice in Chains releases.     When it comes down to it, they made a great piece of music, but a so-so piece of art. What they have is the Alice in Chains shell without the heart and soul that really catapulted them into a truly one-of-a-kind group. To quote T.S. Eliot's poem The Hollow Men, they have \\"shape without form, shade without colour.... gesture without motion.\\"     To compare it to sports, it's like watching Michael Jordan when he came back to play for the Wizards. He showed he was still MJ at times by using his veteran savvy to make viewers and opponents ooooh and awwww, but when it came down to it he just wasn't his airness anymore. It was gratifying to see him back as Jordan, but also gut-wrenching to watch him when he was disadvantaged, knowing how truly great he once was. This is precisely my feeling towards Alice in Chains returning with their name in tact. I cannot be more glad that they are here but find it incredibly hard to stomach at the same time.    More so artistically than musically, Staley was to Alice in Chains as Freddie Mercury was to Queen. You don't have one without the other, and you can't convince a large group of people otherwise. What they do have is a very, very good emulation of Alice that at times might fool you into thinking it's the real deal with their aforementioned Michael Jordan-like veteran savvy, even in the new writing you might think it's the real deal. In a sense what they have is the ultimate Alice in Chains 'cover band'. That's not intended as a sleight at what they've recorded here or what they're doing, but it's just the reality of the situation. And facing reality, even when it's unbearably hopeless to the point where you think life is going to be over (in this case the life of the band), is what Alice in Chains is all about -- with or without Layne Staley physically present. Whether they're doing this to  'honor the legacy', or as they consistently put it as 'playing the songs we all love', all they're doing is what they canwith what they have available. What it really is, is a classic case of  'taking lemons and making lemonade.' Truly this is the case, because the taste left in my mouth over the new material is a little sweet while a little sour, and perhaps even 'a little bitter.'
B002BFBAWO|4.0|I expected this film to be just another silly teen comedy, but 'Adventureland' is a much more serious film than I expected. That's not to say it's without any laughs. The film has an excellent cast who all can handle comedy and drama well. I have only seen Eisenberg in a few films, but he shows he is an interesting and capable actor. I liked this film very much and its charming run down amusement park setting with a cool 80's soundtrack will certainly spark memories for those of us old enough to remember those times.
0525950079|4.0|While I agree that it wasn't quite as good as the first, this one was sufficiently different that I enjoyed it very much.  The pace tends to change throughout the book; some parts are very busy while a few drag on a little too long.  All in all not a problem though.  I recommend.
B002HNA95E|4.0|Madonna has previously released 2 greatest hits sets, 1990's Immaculate Collection, and 2001's GHV2. (You can also throw in 1995's Something To Remember as a hits collection of sorts.) But now comes \\"Celebration\\" (incidentally the last release Madonna was contractually obliged to Warner Records). First things first: this is being released as both a single CD release, and as a \\"deluxe\\" 2CD release. It's immediately clear that the 2CD package is the way to go if you want to get a full overview of Madonna's 27+ year career (and counting).<br /><br />\\"Celebration\\" (2CDs; 36 tracks; 157 min.) is a fabulous overview of Madonna then-and-now (it includes 2 new tracks, the title track and \\"Revolver\\", the latter one not being on the single CD compilation). Would anyone who has The Immaculate Collection and GHV2 CDs be interested in this? Interesting question. 16 of the 17 tracks from the Immaculate Collection are on here, and rightfully so (only \\"Rescue Me\\" is not on here). Several tracks from GHV2 are on here too, but since that compilation was issued in 2001, this brings an updated overview with Madonna's biggest and best tracks since then such as \\"Die Another Day\\", \\"Hung Up\\", and \\"4 Minutes\\", just to name those. In the end, \\"Celebration\\" is a better overview than a collated Immaculate Collection/GHV2 would be, and for that reason alone, this is worth having. That said, I can't help but notice that several huge hits from Madonna's illustrious career are not included on here, such as \\"This Used To Be My Playground\\" and \\"Don't Cry For Me Argentina\\". But at 157 min., this 2CD collection is pretty much maxed out as it is, and what other tracks would one leave off?<br /><br />The sequencing and arguing about whether such-and-such track could've or should've been included aside, this is one stellar collection of music, and a true statement to Madonna's incredible staying power. Hearing the old tunes next to the newer ones (as this compilation is not chronological) such as going from \\"4 Minutes\\" to \\"Holiday\\" on CD1 or \\"Who's That Girl\\" to \\"Frozen\\" on CD2 only re-emphasizes how timeless Madonna has been and has become. It just amazes you. Bottom line, this 2CD \\"Celebration\\" is the ultimate Madonna overview, done right, for the casual Madonna fan (if there is such a thing).\\" to \\"Holiday\\" on CD1 or \\"Who's That Girl\\" to \\"Frozen\\" on CD2 only re-emphasizes how timeless Madonna has been and has become. It just amazes you. Bottom line, this 2CD \\"Celebration\\" is the ultimate Madonna overview, done right, for the casual Madonna fan (if there is such a thing).

1401323820|5.0|As a work of literature, \\"Heat Wave\\" is a sensational success. The story is written with an appropriate tone and just the right balance of wit and accuracy. The information pertaining to the case is appropriately crisp and matter-of-fact while the relationships and interactions between people are genuine and human. The characters are well-developed without being too overbearing or distracting from the woven crime cases. Even a character like Jameson Rook, who is exasperating and arrogant on the best of days, is given just the right amount of human qualities to endear him to the audience. The reader will care about the characters and read eagerly for the solution to the crime.<br /><br />As an adjunct to the ABC comedy crime drama \\"Castle,\\" \\"Heat Wave\\" hits the mark as the creative work of Richard Castle. Fans of the show will recognize his wit and humor in the prose as well as the inclusion of his experiences with the NYPD and Detective Kate Beckett into the story. The characters and their relationships are perfect mirrors to those that Richard Castle experiences with his ride-along at twelfth precinct which makes it an easy transition for fans of the show. ABC has gone to greater lengths than any network I've ever seen to provide their fans with something interactive that directly ties into the show. Far beyond \\"breaking the fourth wall,\\" this book pushes the limit of the artistic world meeting the \\"real world.\\" Fans will feel like they are sharing the experience with their favorite characters from \\"Castle\\" by laying their hands on Richard Castle's first Nikki Heat novel.
0312330537|1.0|While there might be some who rave about this being the greatest novel they've ever read, I have to wonder what are the other novels they've read.  This isn't even, by far, the best book written about contemporary Mumbai, or Bombay, however you refer to the city. The book is a long-winded ode to violence, with Bombay and other locales (Goa, Afghanistan) as an exotic setting for a mafia tale.  The author does create some interesting characters: unfortunately, they are not a lot of the main ones, and the weak spot is the narrator himself, and the Harlequin romance quality prose that accompanies his odes to various loved ones, or descriptions of nature, or Marine Drive during evening, or a kabob stand on Chowpaty Beach, or any one of his male friends in the slums, at Juhu Beach, ad nauseum. Mr. Roberts attempts at metaphor, figurative language and narrative description by and large flounder miserably, leaving the reader feeling vaguely unwell.  And it usually accompanies all passages having to do with his paramour Karla, so a few hundred pages into the book, everytime her name is uttered the reader cringes, bracing themself for more turgid love prose.    He does a decent job of capturing the flavor of Mumbai, from Colaba up to Juhu, VT, back Bay, Marine Drive and other spots, though Sukhetu Mehta's non-fiction \\"Bombay Maximum City\\" is miles ahead of it. The plot is a continuous mob brawl, so it is ironic that the author portrays himself as a good guy whom everybody loves, when he spends most of his time slicing and dicing his way through the city, setting up smack deals, dealing in phony passports.  Its a melodrama with a terminally flawed hero - he can't even muster up much of a love for Karla until well into the book.  With all of the glowing accounts of men fighting, brave gangsters, his love for Khaderbai, was I the only one who detected more than a faint theme of homoeroticism in the book?  And if he reminded us once more about his ability to speak BOTH Marathi and Hindi I was going to vomit.   Did anyone edit this book?  If they did, I shudder to think what it read like before.    Oh, and the philosophizing .... \\"The universe tends towards ever-increasing complexity\\". That sums up the many pages of philosophy in the book....I soon began to skim these pages.  I knew well into the book what would be the final outcome regarding Khader and Karla.  Like a lot of action movies, Roberts piles on pages and detaisl to try to get the reader to forget about what obviously will happen.      There are much better novels about India, written by Indians - Ghosh, Mistry, Rushdie, and many others.  Trudging through this epic (it should be a TV miniseries starring Richard Chamberlain) left me longing for the oeuvre of Shoba De...

It's a charming, well-acted, intelligently written and highly enjoyable coming-of-age story set at a 1980s amusement park.<br /><br />Jesse Eisenberg gives a fine performance as James Brennan, the virginal, insecure, awkwardly intelligent college grad who takes a summer job at Adventureland when his parents' financial troubles force him to cancel his European summer plans.  Kristen Stewart shines as Em, the girl he falls for but who happens to be involved with the park's married maintenance guy.  Stewart makes her character believably screwed up, both in her home life and in how she compartmentalizes and balances her dueling summer relationships.  Meanwhile, Ryan Reynolds makes Mike, the maintenance guy, a tightly wound bundle of emotions, playing him as an aging town stud who understands that while most of the young people who surround him may enjoy a summer of fun, games and meaningless rides, he's the only one who'll be doing it all again next summer.<br /><br />There's a great supporting cast and a fun '80s soundtrack, too.<br /><br />So don't expect SUPERBAD.  But if you do go along for the ride, be prepared to for something super good.

Overall- it's a decent disc- that is still growing on me. Worthy of picking up... Being that they are riding their own rising trajectory, Adam and his Shooting Star bandmates are certainly not going to suddenly pick up and move east.<br /><br />And so it stands, on the lightly snowy morning that Mia and her family depart for a day of visiting and die in a horrific automobile accident.  That is, they all die except for Mia, who finds herself wandering about in an out-of-body state while her body lies in grave condition, in a coma, undergoing a series of operations and lying for hours all wired up in ICU while that quilt of supporters root for her to stay.<br /><br />IF I STAY takes place over the twenty-four hours that follow the accident.  Being that the accident takes place at the beginning of the book, we are moved back and forth throughout the story between the present -- as Mia considers what to do -- and the past as she tells of her life to this point.<br /><br />Will Mia stay or choose to check out?<br /><br />While there is some very cool stuff here about family, friendship, and love, IF I STAY is really an ode to the power of music.  Thinking about Mia's story causes me to recall all the times I have been moved by and forever remember a great live performance, of all the instances when hearing a song has immediately transported me back into that time in my life when it was playing over and over on the radio, of all those times I have reached for a song to help me celebrate when I'm jazzed, lend me solace when I'm low, or remember someone special from the past with whom I used to share music.  Despite knowing better at my age, I still sometimes feel like nobody can possibly be as moved by the opening notes of an old, favorite song to the extent that I am.<br /><br />And I'm betting that Mia feels the same.tion, in a coma, undergoing a series of operations and lying for hours all wired up in ICU while that quilt of supporters root for her to stay.       IF I STAY takes place over the twenty-four hours that follow the accident.  Being that the accident takes place at the beginning of the book, we are moved back and forth throughout the story between the present -- as Mia considers what to do -- and the past as she tells of her life to this point.       Will Mia stay or choose to check out?     While there is some very cool stuff here about family, friendship, and love, IF I STAY is really an ode to the power of music.  Thinking about Mia's story causes me to recall all the times I have been moved by and forever remember a great live performance, of all the instances when hearing a song has immediately transported me back into that time in my life when it was playing over and over on the radio, of all those times I have reached for a song to help me celebrate when I'm jazzed, lend me solace when I'm low, or remember someone special from the past with whom I used to share music.  Despite knowing better at my age, I still sometimes feel like nobody can possibly be as moved by the opening notes of an old, favorite song to the extent that I am.      And I'm betting that Mia feels the same.

B002GU5V24|5.0|Well, pre-order complaints can now fall by the wayside in favor of ACTUAL listening reports ....    This set is awesome, easily my favorite of the four Genesis box set re-releases.  Athough they could have been more extensive, the extras on this set are nice, particularly if you had been hoping for the eventual release of the classic 1973 Rainbow Theater show.  But extras are not the reason to buy this set, glorious sound quality is! All four of the major albums are transformed, with improvements being more significant with the older albums. Genesis Live, for example, has gone from muddy and over-processed, to a dynamic, crystal-clear record that captures the power and brilliance of the early days of the band. The 2-channel versions are very nice, but if you have the gear, the 5.1 channel alternatives are amazing.  My only sore point with this set is that Three Sides Live is not offered here in surround.    There is an empty slot for Live Over Europe, as the view was that most fans would have recently bought it and should not be asked to so again since it had not been remixed or remastered.    This is a great set!

B000003JDO|5.0|Since this is Jethro Tulls' magnum opus, the basic content here needs no introduction. Certainly Ian Anderson is one of the best songwriters around, and  also deserves praise for having captured a particularly magical strand of the English spirit.  If you were only to get one Tull album, this would be it.   Anderson's songwriting technique is more imaginative and dexterous than most other's.  His colleagues are certainly among the most plainly professional in rock.  Regarding the sound, there are some details that are now audible that weren't before.  The acoustics of the overlarge recording space are still a bit of a problem but we are already used to them.  The extra content on the CD is a little redundant but it is extra content.  The interview is particularly welcome; Anderson seems quite coherent, a rarity in Rock music, and personable as well.  Is he really a Rock musician, or just a multi-talented music theater guy who chose a particular path?  He, one of the best singing musicians in Rock, very magnanimously quotes Rolling Stone's ultra-ignorant remarks about his alleged limitations as a singer; one wonders whether such magnanimity is even perceivable at RS, which is more of a political rag nowadays than any kind of musical journal.   If Robert Plant of Led Zeppelin got a bee in his bonnet because Anderson spoke out of turn while unaware of Plant's text-writing, it seems from this interview that he has made his apology permanent, and apologies don't get better than that - Mr. Plant, are you listening?  If there were any chance these two guys could get together, at this point it seems unlikely it would be Anderson's fault if they didn't.  What would make sense would be for the boxed sets to now start coming out... Anderson and his chums have produced quite a lot of material in his career.  It would be a good way to get all that other, less well known music known to the boxed-set-buying generation.   There is so very much of it.

0812971825|5.0|I sank into this book like I would a couch of silk-covered down cushions. I savored word-by-word the life of Reverend Tyler Caskey as he takes up his first church  in a small Vermont town. He brings his somewhat innocent faith and doctrine of total love and acceptance to his flock which embraces him whole-heartedly. They were less enthusiastic about his young wife, Laura, however.<br /><br />The omniscient narrator writes, \\"He had married a summer girl. Almost never- plenty of people would have told you this-was that a good idea. He and married a summer girl from Massachusetts, and that alone brought complications.\\" But when Laura dies shortly after the birth of their second daughter, Caskey slowly crumbles beneath the weight of his grief, the challenge to his faith, and the demands of being a single father. His congregation responds to his stress by exhibiting their own flaws. Through the ensuing struggle, we are introduced to wonderful characters whose minds we enter with incredible ease and whose voices are clearly individual.<br /><br />Abide with Me is Strout's second book and follows Amy and Isabelle (2000), a finalist for the PEN/Faulkner Award. Her new book, Olive Kittredge, is getting rave reviews as well and I look forward to reading it. For writers, Abide with Me provides an excellent opportunity to study two elements of craft: writing from the omniscient point-of-view and development of fallible yet sympathetic characters.<br /><br />Peggy Tabor Millin, author of Women, Writing, and Soul-Making<br />[...]

B0029LHW4U|5.0|You know the story by now: Hard-rock heroes Alice in Chains help forge a new sound for the 1990's, inspiring countless bands in their wake, only to disintegrate before the end of the decade, citing typical rock-star excess and drama (see: drug abuse). Any chance of a meaningful reunion is seemingly squashed when frontman Layne Staley is found dead of a heroin overdose in April of 2002, after falling off the face of the Earth completely. That is, until the surviving members -- Jerry Cantrell, Mike Inez and Sean Kinney - reunite in 2005, acquiring new vocalist William DuVall (Comes With The Fall) the following year, and do enough touring to decide that, yes, an Alice in Chains reunion is worth it and a new album is in order.<br /><br />\\"Black Gives Way to Blue\\" has a big task at hand: Retain a signature sound while re-establishing the band as a force to be reckoned with, in spite of losing their iconic singer. Ladies and gentlemen, I am happy to announce that not only do Alice in Chains accomplish that goal, but that they are back and much bigger and better than one could have ever expected. With producer Nick Raskulinecz (Foo Fighters, Stone Sour) in tow, Cantrell and company have managed to produce an album that sounds exactly like themselves and is as bold and fresh as anything they have done in their career. The sludgy-riffs, dominant rhythm section and the haunting harmonized vocals are all in place and make for a signature Alice in Chains experience. If fourteen years between albums was too much to bear, rest assured, this album does its best to make up for lost time.<br /><br />Without a doubt, guitarist/vocalist Jerry Cantrell has taken his rightful spot as frontman on this album, following the loss of Staley. While many may fear that this new incarnation of Alice in Chains is simply a re-dressed version of Cantrell's solo career, it's anything but. The first couple of songs are pure Cantrell/old-school Alice in Chains, but when William DuVall comes through on \\"Last of My Kind,\\" a classic is born and a singer that more than fills the shoes is established. Fact of the matter is, not only is this NOT a solo Cantrell affair, but that DuVall is more than worthy of filling the position left vacant. Likewise, Inez and Kinney are still up to snuff and add the extra weight that always nailed home the best Alice in Chains songs.<br /><br />Thankfully for longtime fans and purists alike, the album pays as much tribute to the band's past as it paves a new path. The first single, \\"Check My Brain\\" is exactly the kind of hard-driving hard-rock that Alice in Chains were known for (see: \\"Facelift\\") while \\"Your Decision\\" and \\"When the Sun Rose Again\\" echo back to the \\"Jar of Flies\\" and \\"Sap\\" glory-days. Oh, and who could forget Elton John, who makes an appearance behind the piano on the title track? The most somber moment of the album, the closing number seemingly pays tribute to and closes the door on Layne Staley in a rather bittersweet and appropriate fashion.<br /><br />The song-writing is there and the musicianship is top-notch, as is the production. From front to back, there isn't a bad song to be found and even the most jaded and loyal fans of Staley will have to concede that it more than lives up to its name. Alice in Chains aren't trying to re-live glory days with this album, but it's certainly an extension of them. If you thought they were dragging the name out to make a quick buck, you better guess again. \\"Black Gives Way to Blue\\" means business and is about the biggest and baddest rock album you'll come across these days, proving what we always knew: Alice in Chains were one of the best things to happen to rock, not just in the `90's, but in general.d,\\" a classic is born and a singer that more than fills the shoes is established. Fact of the matter is, not only is this NOT a solo Cantrell affair, but that DuVall is more than worthy of filling the position left vacant. Likewise, Inez and Kinney are still up to snuff and add the extra weight that always nailed home the best Alice in Chains songs.    Thankfully for longtime fans and purists alike, the album pays as much tribute to the band's past as it paves a new path. The first single, \\"Check My Brain\\" is exactly the kind of hard-driving hard-rock that Alice in Chains were known for (see: \\"Facelift\\") while \\"Your Decision\\" and \\"When the Sun Rose Again\\" echo back to the \\"Jar of Flies\\" and \\"Sap\\" glory-days. Oh, and who could forget Elton John, who makes an appearance behind the piano on the title track? The most somber moment of the album, the closing number seemingly pays tribute to and closes the door on Layne Staley in a rather bittersweet and appropriate fashion.    The song-writing is there and the musicianship is top-notch, as is the production. From front to back, there isn't a bad song to be found and even the most jaded and loyal fans of Staley will have to concede that it more than lives up to its name. Alice in Chains aren't trying to re-live glory days with this album, but it's certainly an extension of them. If you thought they were dragging the name out to make a quick buck, you better guess again. \\"Black Gives Way to Blue\\" means business and is about the biggest and baddest rock album you'll come across these days, proving what we always knew: Alice in Chains were one of the best things to happen to rock, not just in the `90's, but in general.

B002BSHWUU|5.0|Ignore all the reviews which want to nit pick this technology or that technology which should or should not have been used. If you're into listening for absolute technical perfection then go stand near a Ferrari. If you want to listen to the Beatles the way they have never sounded before on record, tape or CD then these remastered recordings are your ticket. The bottom end of Paul's bass and Ringo's drums never sounded so crisp and deep. Even on Pepper which utilized bounce tracking a 4 track machine to get the equivalent of 16 tracks sounds masterful. Bounce tracking by its very nature will muddy the lows but you would never know it on this CD. So sit back, relax and listen... a splendid time is guaranteed for all :-) BnB Beatles Depot.

B0029LHW4U|4.0|After the sad demise of Staley, who knew if a new AIC album will see the light of day! People kinda accepted the fact that this is it for AIC! Years after.. now.. we have \\"Black Gives Way To Blue\\" with \\"William Duvall\\" taking on vocal & rhythm section duties! I must say, Duvall is a remarkable singer, he notably hits the highs and lows that could kick any AIC fan back to Staley Land! I've listened to the whole album twice so far, & I cant help but notice how much \\"in-sync\\" Duvall is with the whole band! The Music just flows.. very little change in sound I'd say.
